ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: How to read and interpret medical and scientific journals, as well as write about science and medicine for a lay audience. Each assignment tackled a different writing style, ranging from news reports to op eds.
I learned how to write like a science journalist!
Improved my ability to write/edit non-fiction prose on science, medicine, and public health.

I learned how to write more effectively, clearly, and passionately. We really dug into the craft of writing by studying so many amazing science/medical writers of the past. Not to mention the amazing speakers who came in to chat about their real world experience. I learned how to pitch in journalism, craft an angle, spot gold coins, structure effectively, and improve draft after draft.

As a result of this class, I improved my ability to write about scientific topics which require a different set of skills than other topics. I learned the importance of simplifying scientific topics and providing accessible explanations to complicated issues.
My writing improved/ learned how to write for different audiences / learned how to edit my sentences

A deep understanding of the nuances of different forms of medical writingscience news, patient profile, op ed, book review, long form creative non-fiction. If you're thinking about a future in medicine, this is the WR course to take.

How to talk about science and medicine in engaging ways and accurately tell the stories of patients and doctors.
How to craft ledes and nut grafs. How to find the stories that aren't being told, conduct interviews, and find the right balance between opinion and objectivity.
writing ledes and nutgrafs, analyzing scientific information, interviewing, writing techniques

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Very detailed feedback, lots of communication with Professor Epstein, interesting readings and assignments. 
Weaknesses: Lots of readings and assignments

Strength is Dr. Epstein. She cares so much and is one of the kindest professors I've ever met in my years here. She is a source of infinite help and resources. If you are interested in journalism or health profession or some combination of both, she is the professor you want to talk to.

Strengths: Outstanding & accessible professor who makes class engaging and rewarding. Fun student workshops, eye-opening lab visits, and informative speaker events. Prompt, clear feedback on all writing and fair grading.

Weaknesses: High workload. Lengthy readings that I sometimes didn't find relevant/helpful.

This class has a fantastic curriculum. I mean the readings, the speakers, the discussion, the workshoppingwe even had out of class trips and experiences. Professor Epstein puts her all into teaching and it shows.

Strengths: Detailed feedback, Dr. Epstein is incredibly helpful and accessible, final paper is a satisfying process

Weaknesses: Grading felt inconsistent at times, but not a major issue.
I loved this course and I wouldn't really change anything about it.
strengths: the field trips to museum and pathology lab, the feedback and office hours, in class contests, the readings and the guest writers! no weaknesses, a great course

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to any pre-med or anyone interested in writing about science or medicine. Even if youre not a humanities person, this class will help you become a much better writer.

I would wholeheartedly recommend this class to aspiring journalists or premeds. I almost felt like I was getting to indulge myself by writing about what I actually cared about, not about some random piece of literature about dead English people that I could not care less about. Writing came easy because I wanted to know more, even outside of the class. This course is so enriching for you and ACTUALLY makes you learn how to write. Premeds, take note!

Strongly recommend to anyone interested in/looking to improve their science/medical writing. Prof. Epstein is a fantastic teacher who makes the class fun, engaging, and rewarding despite its high workload. You'll get to participate in a variety of fun events (i.e. talks from authors/journalists, visiting a pathology lab, visiting art museums, etc.) and will improve your ability to write nonfiction prose considerably.

Absolutely. Im so grateful to know Professor Epstein, especially as someone hoping to go into journalism. Everyone was pretty daunted by the prospect of the final project, but she whipped us into shape by the end in a way that prepared us well to tackle big topics. You will really feel your growth. If you have any interest in medicine or writing, you have to take this class because you will grow not only as a writer, but as a connoisseur of medical/scientific knowledge. There is so much beauty in learning how to write (and read!) well.
Yes, regardless of your interests this course will enhance your ability to write about topics clearly and powerfully.
YESS. This was by far the best course I have ever taken and the professor is absolutely amazing.

Yes, I would highly recommend this course to any student looking to learn about scientific and medical writing. We attempted an interesting diversity of essays, including a news story, a patient profile, a book review, a small screenplay, an opinion piece, and a long journalism piece. Each of them required me to understand different aspects of scientific communication, and I left the class as a much more well-rounded writer.
take this class if you are interested in writing or medicine. such a helpful perspective for learning how to translate scientific information
